intro: Carphalea cloiselii, commonly known as the Mexican moonflower, is a flowering plant native to Mexico and parts of Central America. It is a member of the Acanthaceae family and is characterized by its showy, white, tubular flowers that bloom at night. The plant has opposite, ovate leaves with a slightly hairy texture, and it produces small, round fruits that contain seeds. It thrives in warm, humid climates and is often found in moist, shaded environments. Due to its unique blooming pattern and ornamental value, it is occasionally cultivated in botanical gardens and by plant enthusiasts.
